dt: {bc}having the power of entering, piercing, or pervading

shortdef: having the power of entering, piercing, or pervading

dt.t: this route … {wi}penetrates{/wi} the leading resort and lake areas
Only a dirt road {wi}penetrates{/wi} the rough, wooded terrain.
an apartment that I now {it}penetrated{/it} for the first time
their keen eyes can {wi}penetrate{/wi} the water to a depth of … forty feet

dt: {bc}to discover the inner contents or meaning of

dt.t: a scientific secret which will eventually be {it}penetrated{/it} by other countries
men may still be {it}penetrated{/it} with awe by the divine righteousness
the cold began to {wi}penetrate{/wi} his bones

dt: {bc}to pass, extend, pierce, or diffuse into or through something

dt.t: fishes … which enter tidal rivers and {wi}penetrate{/wi} almost to fresh water

dt: {bc}to pierce something with the eye or mind

dt.t: strained his eyes to {wi}penetrate{/wi} beyond the thick cloud of dust
insight that {wi}penetrates{/wi} to the very heart of some … problem

dt: {bc}to affect deeply the senses or feelings

dt.t: the suggestion might {wi}penetrate{/wi} deeply enough … to make her a good deal more wary

pt: {sc}enter{/sc} {sc}penetrate{/sc} {sc}pierce{/sc} {sc}probe{/sc} mean to make way into something. {sc}enter{/sc} is the most general of these and may imply either going in or forcing a way in.
{sc}penetrate{/sc} carries a strong implication of an impelling force or compelling power that achieves entrance.
{sc}pierce{/sc} means an entering or cutting through with a sharp pointed instrument.
{sc}probe{/sc} implies penetration to investigate or explore something hidden from sight or knowledge.

et: Latin {it}penetratus{/it}, past participle of {it}penetrare{/it}, from {it}penitus{/it} deep within, far; akin to Latin {it}penus{/it} provisions
shortdef: to enter by overcoming resistance : pierce
